column5: I'm looking to update my sleeping bag for our fly-in trips. Looking for some recommendations from some WC members. Priorities are lightweight, compact and reasonably priced. We usually take our trips in July or August so I don't need one for below 30-40°.
I'd say a blanket would do the trick.but nature can turn nasty even in July.id get a middle of the road one.they weigh nothing so it wouldn't effect the weight your allowed on the plane.

No need to spend a lot of dough on a bag you’re only going to use a once a year or so in warm weather. You can get a good bag for under $50 at the usual sporting goods stores. I suggest the following features.• Rectangular shape - Roomiest and also allows you to unzip it fully to be used as a blanket - Comes in handy when it is too hot to sleep in the bag. I also bring an old sheet to cover the mattress. Mummy bags can’t do that.• Nylon exterior material – easier to keep clean. Flannel lined bag may feel more comfy but they get dirtier and smellier. • Synthetic insulation will work just fine. Yeah, down will be a tad lighter and insulate best, but you don’t need to pay for those advantages. Also, the synthetic bag will perform better and dry faster if gotten wet.• Get a good stuff sack (should be included with the bag) to protect the bag and save storage space.

I use this one. It's worked well. You can sleep in it zipped up or unzip and use like a blanket. In the compression sack it's about 8" x 15" and weights about 2 1/2 lbs.https://www.cabelas.com/product/Eure...ag/2253864.uts
Thanks! That's the kid of info I'm looking for!

another thing to consider is to simply make a bed roll - I really dislike the restrictions of a sleeping bag so I bring a bed roll that includes an old fitted single sheet, regular sheet and a light comforter. roll a pillow up in these a I think you have a much more comfortable sleeping situation for little if any additional weight. phish
That's a good idea too. Thanks!
Always take a light sheet to cover with in case it's warm and the skeeters are bad!

I found a very good sleeping bag at WalMart for under $40.00. It rolls up in a small bag. 10 by 5. 20 to 50 degrees range. I also take a similar size rolled up fleece throw if it is colder, if not then it makes a good pillow.
